text: if you're figuring out how to actually integrate AI improve your platform or
make dev experience better for your team InfoQ DevSummit Boston 2025 might be
worth checking out It's 2 days in June focused on the real world side of
adopting these technologies You'll hear from senior engineers who have already been through
it what worked what didn't and what they do differently It's built for teams who
need to move now not just stay inspired Join us this June 9 to
10 Learn more at
[Music] dicksummit.infoq.com Good day folks This
is Shane Hasty for the InfoQ Engineering Culture Podcast Today I'm sitting down with Erin Doyle Erin welcome Thanks for
taking the time to talk to us Thank you Really excited to be here My normal
starting point on these conversations is is Aaron I would describe myself as a a
generalist a jack of all trades I've done a lot over the course of my career
Started out at the Kennedy Space Center doing full stack development for the the workers who would work on the space
shuttle After that I did sort of product support customer support solutions engineering which I wouldn't say was my
favorite job but I learned a lot about troubleshooting debugging jumping into
code that I didn't write and that was pretty valuable After that I did mobile
development which I was brand new to and it was new to the company So that was an
exciting journey And then I moved on to a full stack uh e-commerce team and that's when
I really dove deep into web accessibility because that was a huge priority for the product and uh had to
learn all about that And so then I I kind of got into talking and teaching workshops on web
accessibility and then after that I did a little consultancy which was another completely different experience had to
do everything all the front all the back all the DevOps and then eventually I moved over to platform team So I'd done
full stack development forever and then I got into platform development because I I love the idea of supporting
developers as my customers I love doing the work to help enable you know my
teammates fellow developers to uh work more efficiently effectively And so I
got to do a lot more of that over on the platform team Uh got to wear a lot of hats S sur DevX
Devpro Ops everything So now my final step in my journey I just started a new
job as a founding engineer at Quotient where we do bel de development productivity software So that's been
kind of a a dream of mine and of course as a founding engineer I get to wear all the hats So it's kind of the buildup of
my career has led to this and I'm really excited about it Thank you So let's dig
in first in the one of those early passions accessibility web
accessibility Um why does it matter so much Yeah it's
huge And primarily it was huge to our customers at that company because um we
had a a white label application for businesses and these are businesses
selling a product And so a there was a lot of um legal ramifications of
websites that are trying to sell product if they're not accessible People could sue for that And and we did have
customers who had been sued for their own websites in the past So it was a huge priority for them to be safe from
legal action but also if a customer can't check out if a customer can't buy your product you're not making as much
money So unfortunately the bottom line for the business is you know maybe not
altruistic but that's where it started And once it started and we could get into that I could start talking to
people about we need to do this because we care because accessibility matters to all of us we
should all have an equal experience using the web and mobile It's become our
world Everything we do is online And so if we're if we're blocking people from
being able to do the things they need to be able to do the things they want to be able to do you know that's just not
right And so to care about our fellow human we want to make these
experiences equal and accessible So those are kind of the big reasons why legal to make money and because we care
about our fellow humans What does good
accessibility come down to I think it's it's really understanding your users
your audience and how they're approaching your product So you know
there's a whole range of limitations I'm not even going to just call them disabilities because sometimes it's
limitations Sometimes it's a it's a temporary limitation that any of us could run into at any point in time
Could be environmental it could be health related like whatever it's it's
that many of us may approach using the web with some sort of limitation Whether
it's um manual meaning like we can't use our hands in the same ways Maybe we
can't use a mouse Maybe we have dexterity issues Maybe it's visual We
either blind or color blind or just have impairment in your vision Maybe it's
auditory You can't hear if if there's something that's um playing So there's a lot of different
ways that people might be limited And so we need to understand based on those limitations how are they using the web
how are they using computers how are they using mobile devices and then actually experiencing that So I think
really we have to try to put ourselves in their shoes as best we can and test out our applications using those same
approaches that they might be using Maybe it's keyboard only Maybe you can
uh up the contrast Um there's lots of color contrast tools that maybe people
who are color blind might use I've found issues where suddenly buttons on the
page disappeared when the contrast was turned up on the site and so people wouldn't even know that those were there
screen readers Every device has options of screen readers and so actually using
your site with a screen reader or andor keyboard only is quite a different
experience So really approaching your site with all of those and kind of
seeing like what is that user experience like and how do we need to modify it Are there things that we need
to have the screen reader announce to people Are there things that as the
state of the page changes we need to let them know like this thing is visible now or there's an error and here it is What
what is it and where is it Um so we need to just kind of like approach the user
experience differently And that's why it really helps if you can get you know designers involved in this So it's it's
not landing at the development stage It's sort of like what is the user
experience for someone using a screen reader What is it for someone using a keyboard etc So then we can develop
matching those experiences There are guidelines Are they useful
It can be overwhelming you know if you go to the various guidelines that are
out there or if you look at the uh uh
legal well and they vary by country So you know what the laws are in the US for
for accessibility are going to be different from the EU and and and so forth So approaching it from that
direction can be really overwhelming Like what are all the guidelines How do I go through a checklist and and make
sure my site is doing all of these things There are a lot of tools that help us that kind of audit for the
lowhanging fruit the things that are just easier to catch not just statically
but but even a runtime We've got tools that you can run in the browser that as the state of the site changes it can
detect those things But again those are the really easier things to catch So you
can at least start there You know I've always recommended taking a test-driven approach Instead of starting with the
guidelines and trying to make sure you're matching them start with a test-driven approach Add the tools that
are going to make your job a little easier Catch the lowhanging fruit and have it tell you like this is
inaccessible And usually they're really good at telling you why You can get to more documentation that tells you why is
this important Why is this a problem Here's some recommendations on how to fix it And so you can kind of build up
your knowledge set bit by bit of like okay these are the things we typically need to look for and these are the ways
we typically fix them and then you know you can create shared component libraries and things like that So you
really only need to fix it once and it's going to kind of roll out to multiple places So there are ways to kind of help
you be more efficient and kind of get your arms around like all these things to learn and and make sure you're doing
But after that you really have to like I said you have to test the app You have
to find the rough edges of like oh this experience is terrible or maybe
technically this is accessible but it's really hard to do what I need to do and
then you know adjust that because we care about the user experience or we should But you can go so far as auditors
There are many auditors out there that will test your site and will really go through the checklist and make sure
you're fully compliant There are certifications out there you can get But what's tough is it's a moving target You
know every time you add a new feature every time you make a change you might inadvertently have just broken something
about the accessibility of your site So it kind of needs to be baked into the QA process as well to make sure you're
constantly testing and auditing for these things and as our styles of
interaction change So I'm I'm thinking the for many people today the AI chatbot
that's becoming well becoming the core UI How do we adapt to as developers How
do we adapt to this um the new demands
Yeah Again we just have to be constantly testing constantly learning and and
looking into those things That's a great point is that this has become sort of a
new UI uh paradigm that we're running into a
lot And it may be that many of these chat bots I mean it's it's it's one thing just to figure out just to learn
how do I even add this AI chatbot but then digging into making it accessible
So we can't just tack on these things and not continue to do our due diligence
to make sure the experience is still accessible Because if this is going to
become the main way you interface with these products you know you've just taken a site that might have been
accessible for a lot of people and now added this huge barrier It kind of goes
along with these overlays I'm I'm sure you've seen various websites that have
you know this little icon somewhere the bottom of the page and um with some sort
of accessibility icon on it And these overlay products
really sell themselves as like we're going to do all this for you All you have to do is add this this little thing
to your code and we're going to magically make it accessible You don't have to be an expert on accessibility
you just throw this in And that's really false You know there are some ways that
these overlays actually make things less accessible Many of them add in their own
screen reader but it's not as capable as the the screen readers that are either built into the OS or that are natively
available So they really don't fix or make anything better They actually
hamper the accessibility So there's no shortcuts like just like everything else
in software development like we have to learn our craft We have to learn languages and frameworks and tools and
and this should just really be one of the things that everybody well not everybody front-end developers that just
kind of becomes part of your tool set becomes part of your skill set
Switching topics slightly you made the point of your very
wide experience has brought you to a state where you are comfortable now
building products for engineers in that that platform enablement devx type
space What's different when you are building products for engineers
Yeah I mean you know first of all what drew me there was you know empathy I
firsthand understand that experience when you have a workflow that's painful
when you have friction in your day-to-day work you know your feedback loops are slow or there's just something
awkward or annoying or painful or whatever that you're constantly being hampered and impeded and and just doing
the work that you need to do I know how frustrating that is I also know how hard
it is to be on a product development team where you're constantly under
schedule pressure Uh we've got this feature we've got to get out We've got this looming deadline We don't have time
to go make this thing better or make this easier for us So we're just going to kind of put up with the pain put up
with these things that slow us down We're used to it whatever maybe after
the next feature launches we can come back to it make it better and that that you know maybe in the future never
happens and so I've experienced that over the years and and I was always drawn to taking on those tasks of trying
to make those things better for my team so that my team members can stay heads
down focused on getting those features out and I can try to help enable them to be more efficient Uh so I've always felt
passionate about that So when I had a chance to join a platform team you know that was sort of my argument of I know I
don't have a lot of experience in the ops space or the DevOps space I've got some but I think I bring a perspective
of what it's like to be a product development engineer and what it's like to deal with these things that are that
are constantly getting in my way and what it's like to work with a platform
or DevOps team what it's like to be on the other side of the wall And so I'm I
was hoping to bring with that this empathy this understanding of the developer perspective And uh you know
there are all these stereotypes of uh you know when you're on the dev side you
might be thinking uh um I really need help with this thing but if I reach out
to platform or devops they're going to think I'm stupid or they don't have time They're so busy with all this stuff that
they have to do they don't have time to help me with this thing or we kind of
speak different languages You know they might be saying something that's that's totally over my head and that might be a
little intimidating So you know I have that I I understand what that's like and
and I have felt hampered in the past from collaborating or asking for help
from the DevOps team or the platform team So jumping to the other side was
really fascinating to see the perspective of the platform team working with developers Developers who are
constantly being pushed and rushed and kind of forced to cut corners and thus create problems that the platform team
has to solve or SRRES have to solve And so then there's this stereotyper of devs
are lazy devs are always cutting corners devs don't care about quality or they
don't do their due diligence before they do a thing and they don't want to collaborate with us You know when we ask
them to work with us to do something like database upgrades for instance we
need to work with them because they need to test their code to make sure it still works with the thing we've upgraded But
they don't have time for this they don't make time for these kinds of things because it's not on their product
roadmap So I saw both sides of of uh you know how we see each other over the wall
But having empathy for like what it's like to actually be in the shoes of either side was super powerful for me
And I was able to explain you know to my teammates I know we think that maybe the
devs are being lazy or or maybe they they should know more about this thing that we're having to help them with but
they don't have time You know they're taking on such a high cognitive load especially these days like as we've
added you know so much in the cloud as we've added so much tooling we've got so many products we've got so many options
now And we've shifted left so much You
know the DevOps movement shifted a lot left to developers The you build it you
run it Developers have to be responsible for a lot a lot of infrastructure a lot
of architectural decisions uh security Even as we just spoke about web accessibility like we've put a lot on
their plates And so in order to continue to meet their deadlines they are forced to
cut corners they they aren't able to learn how to use every tool and and how
to really be knowledgeable about everything in the landscape So to kind
of explain that to my platform team members of like we've got to keep in mind the context here of of what they're
dealing with and then on the other end how can we as a platform team kind of
change how uh we are seen or interpreted by the developers so that when they do
need help they'll ask for it So they're comfortable asking for the help they need when they have to reach into this
space of like creating new infrastructure for the feature they need or getting the right amount of
observability on some new feature when they need that help We need to be
approachable We need to be available or else they're going to do it on their own Again going back to the DevOps movement
we kind of have this concept of devs should just be able to do it all on their own uh in order to move quickly
but that's asking too much these days And so we you know I really wanted to
promote this idea of like we can meet you where you're at The platform team
can can stretch over the aisle and meet you where you're at And so if you don't know how to use these tools if you're
not knowledgeable about the various infrastructure options available these days let's collaborate on it Let's work
on the architectural design together you know bring us in as a partner so that we
can help you do these things to get that feature um ready for production instead
of the developer shouldering it all and not doing as good a job of it be because
they're in an area they're not experienced in They're doing their best but if they don't have that deep
experience they're going to make mistakes They're going to miss things And when they miss things it becomes the
platform team or the S sur team's problem later We're going to have to fix that problem that blows up in production
way down the road Or we're going to find that we're totally missing observability about something and maybe we have errors
or we have problems that that we don't even know are happening or we're not scaling appropriately Like there's so
many outcomes based on just that that interaction of devs trying to do more
than they really are are uh experienced or set up for success to do and not
feeling comfortable asking for help or collaborating with the platform team So
building psychological safety where they feel comfortable they feel safe they
don't feel judged being able to reach out and say "I really need help with this aspect of this feature I'm working
on." Psychological safety an incredibly important concept that's become a
buzzword What does it really mean to create a
safe environment where people can ask those slightly embarrassing questions or
difficult questions Yeah I found that the more I learn about psychological safety the more I start to
see it everywhere and I start to see that sort of chain reaction or kind of
root cause analysis on negative outcomes being the result of a lack of
psychological safety And it can be complex It can be subtle because we're
humans We're humans interacting with other humans and we're all approaching
those interactions with preconceived notions and you know whatever our histories are whatever our psychological
issues are So it's complicated but I've really found and it's been hard for me
that the more that I can model vulnerability myself and especially as I've become more senior over the
years the more that I can show that there are things I don't know or there mistakes that I make there's questions I
have the more I hope I'm creating this environment for other people to feel like they can do the same You know as I
was earlier on in my career as I was just starting to become more senior I felt a ton of pressure to
prove myself to prove that I deserved the role And you know that created a lot of
bad behavior I was a perfectionist I was a workaholic If there was something I
didn't know I couldn't admit it and I couldn't ask for help because then people would know that I didn't know
everything and I wasn't you know the best So it was really hard to to take on
all that pressure of like oh jeez I don't know this thing but I don't want anybody to know that I don't know So now
I'm going to work extra hours I'm going to work all weekend to learn this thing and try to present myself as if I knew
it all along And that's really unhealthy And as sort of a negative side effect I
kind of created this this model or I set this bar to my teammates that they had to be perfect too uh when when I never
made any mistakes I always knew everything I had all the answers then then they felt especially the the more
junior people they thought like "Oh this is the standard." And so I too can't ask
questions I too can't ask for help cuz cuz I guess we don't do that here And so I created a really toxic environment
around myself without realizing it And so as I got you know a little more senior a little more experienced and I
and I finally started hearing people talking about this I I think that's another thing that's changed a lot over the years As more people talk about
culture as more people talk about psychology and working together the more
I was hearing things about psychological safety and how we can impact others with
our behavior when we're not cognizant about the model we're setting for others
So it was really hard for me to go from that perfectionist I have to be perfect
I have to prove myself to you know what I have to make mistakes I have to show
people that I don't know everything if I want them to feel comfortable working with me if I want us to be able to
collaborate And I did see examples of where maybe I didn't make the
environment comfortable for others And I and I knew that they had questions or I
knew that they had things they wanted to say you know that I'd find out later that they didn't say to me or they
didn't ask me And so I realized like oh I'm not making people feel comfortable
approaching me or being open with me with their thoughts or disagreeing with me That's a big thing If I don't make
the environment comfortable for people to feel like they can offer an alternate view of something you know if I make a
statement if I pose a thought if I do that in a way that's too assertive
uh it could cause other people to feel like oh well she must know better than I do Or if I offer this contrary viewpoint
I'm going to sound stupid you know whatever it may be whatever that fear is that they're having in their mind I'm
now not going to hear that alternate viewpoint I might be wrong I'm wrong all the time Maybe there's just some aspect
of this that I'm missing or or something that I don't have personal experience with And so if if I'm kind of shutting
off that opportunity to hear that you know maybe that was a better idea than what I had maybe they thought of
something that I that I didn't and I missed And so we're so much better off
when we can make people feel comfortable saying "Oh well what about this or have you thought about that?" without fear of
I don't know it being taken personally it feeling like conflict So somehow we
have to create that environment where it's not personal it's just normal We
can have discourse and it's comfortable and it's normal and it's how we do our work But again you have to sort of plant
the seeds You have to lay the foundation and that comes from senior people modeling that behavior You know it
really I noticed it as I was you know gaining experience when I would see
those people that I looked up to that I thought were really smart talented when
I saw that like they weren't perfect that there was things that they didn't know and they and they felt comfortable
they weren't ashamed they weren't apologetic they were just like "Hey I've got this question." or oh I just broke
this thing in prod And uh you know just so you know I'm fixing it but it's not apologetic It's not scraping It's not
"Oh I'm I'm so sorry I broke prod I'm so embarrassed." Like we don't have to be
embarrassed We make mistakes And so when you've got that attitude of like "Yeah I
I made this mistake Just FYI I'm working on it." It really lowers that barrier
for us all to be open about like "Yep I made this mistake here's what we're going to do about it Or I could use some
help I missed this thing Or I'm not really knowledgeable about this area that I'm working in Maybe someone else
is Maybe they can help me And so the more we can just make that normal part
of just how we work the more we can allow space for all those things that if if we didn't have
we're not doing our best work Being vulnerable leading by example it's hard
Yeah it's really hard sometimes Like I almost equate it to I don't know if
you've ever jumped off something high up like jumped off into the water or Well
yeah I guess you'd usually be jumping into water but if you've ever taken a leap you know I have a fear of heights
so that's really scary for me I'm never going to go skydiving or bungee jumping But those concepts of I'm
going to take a leap and I have to believe that I'm going to be fine It's
just this kind of scary little thing that I have to get over But I have the
belief that I'm going to be fine is what pushes me to take that step I feel that way all the time I
still to this day feel that way all the time I'll have a question or a problem or whatever and I'll pause and I'll
think if I ask this maybe I'll sound stupid this could be embarrassing
whatever I still have those thoughts but then I just remind myself of like that's
okay You know that that this is okay and you know that you showing this little
bit of vulnerability on a regular basis is going to help someone else So that's
what kind of helps me take that leap There are a lot of really good insights
and good advice in there If people want to continue the conversation where can
they find you Um yeah the easiest place is probably LinkedIn Um I'm on there and I
do have my own website It's got a few blog pages on it Uh unfortunately not as
many as I'd like And it's also got you know whatever talks I've done or or articles I've been featured in you know
whatever I'm doing out in the community is listed there And that's just a doyle.dev
